persona: You are a Chinese real estate agent in her mid-50s working in the Bay Area. English is your second language and you primarily use LLMs to iterate on your listing descriptions and help write ads for the homes you sell. You also use it to sense-check translations and edit phrases to sound more natural.
topic: Phrase a gentle reminder to a seller to tidy the kitchen before photos; you’re uncomfortable giving criticism and want it to read like friendly advice.

conversation.content: Can you help me write a short message to remind my seller to tidy the kitchen before the photographer comes? I want it to sound friendly, not like I’m criticizing.

Here's a friendly reminder message you can send to your seller:

"Hi [Seller's Name], hope you're doing well! Just a quick reminder that the photographer is coming soon to take photos of the house. Would you mind giving the kitchen a quick tidy before they arrive? It'll really help showcase the space in its best light. Thanks so much for your help with this, and I'm looking forward to seeing the photos!"

This message is polite and considerate, and frames the request as a helpful suggestion rather than a criticism. It also acknowledges the seller's efforts and expresses appreciation for their cooperation.
Can you make it sound a little more casual, like something I’d text instead of an email? Maybe drop the “hope you’re doing well” part.

Here's a more casual version of the message:

"Hey! Just a heads up that the photographer is coming soon to take pics of the house. Would you mind giving the kitchen a quick tidy before they arrive? It'll really help make it look its best. Thanks!"

This version is shorter and more conversational, making it suitable for a text message. I've also dropped the more formal language and focused on the main point of the message. Let me know if you'd like any further adjustments!
Can you make it a bit softer? I don’t want it to sound like I’m telling them what to do.

Here's a revised version:

"Hey! Just a reminder that the photographer is coming soon. If you have a chance to tidy up the kitchen a bit, that would be great - it'll really help the photos turn out well. Thanks!"

This version is a bit more gentle and suggestive, rather than directive. By saying "if you have a chance" and "that would be great", you're making it clear that it's a request rather than a requirement. This should help the seller feel more in control and less like they're being told what to do.
Can you add a short line at the end that sounds friendly, maybe something like “excited to see how great it looks”?

Here's the revised message:

"Hey! Just a reminder that the photographer is coming soon. If you have a chance to tidy up the kitchen a bit, that would be great - it'll really help the photos turn out well. Thanks! I'm really looking forward to seeing how everything comes together - I know it's going to look amazing!"

This adds a friendly and positive note to the end of the message, which should help keep the tone light and enthusiastic. The phrase "I know it's going to look amazing" is especially helpful, as it shows that you have confidence in the seller's home and are excited about the upcoming photos.
Can you make that last sentence shorter so it feels more natural in a text? Something upbeat but not too much.

This version still conveys a positive and enthusiastic tone, but in a more concise way that feels natural for a text message. The phrase "Excited to see how it all comes together" is short and upbeat, and helps to end the message on a friendly note.
That sounds good. Could you make one version a little warmer, like something I’d send to a longtime client I really like?

"Hey! Just a heads up that the photographer is coming soon. If you could tidy up the kitchen a bit, that would be a huge help - it'll make the photos look amazing! Thanks so much! Can't wait to see how it all turns out - you're going to love it!"

This version is a bit more personal and friendly, with a warmer tone that's suitable for a longtime client you have a good relationship with. The added phrase "you're going to love it" is a nice touch, as it shows you're thinking of their feelings and are excited for them to see the final result.
